tables.description: Product catalog for FireKicks athletic shoe lines. Each row represents a unique shoe product (SKU) with pricing, categorization, and lifecycle dates. Contains approximately 200 products across running, basketball, casual, training, and kids categories.

relationships.description: Products are referenced in order line items via product_id
Each product has one supplier
Each product has inventory records per warehouse
Each product may have multiple customer reviews
Products appear in return records
One summary row per product in the performance view

qualityNotes.freshness: static catalog, updated when products are added/discontinued

tables.usageNotes: Primary product dimension table. Join to order_items for sales analysis. Use product_performance view for pre-aggregated product metrics instead of manual aggregation. Check discontinued_date IS NULL to filter to active products only.

tables.description: Supplier master data for shoe manufacturing partners. Contains supplier details including country of origin, lead time in days, quality ratings, and primary material type. Linked to products via supplier_id for supply chain traceability.

relationships.description: Each supplier provides one or more products

tables.usageNotes: Supplier dimension table. Join to products via supplier_id to analyze product cost or quality by supplier attributes. Useful for supply chain risk analysis by country or lead time.

tables.description: Current inventory levels by product and warehouse location. Tracks quantity on hand and reorder points for stock management. Each row represents a product-warehouse combination with the last restock date for supply chain monitoring.
tables.grain: One row per product per warehouse location

relationships.description: Each inventory record references a product

qualityNotes.freshness: snapshot data, represents a point-in-time inventory position

tables.usageNotes: Use for stock analysis and reorder alerting. To get total inventory across all warehouses for a product, SUM(quantity_on_hand) GROUP BY product_id. Compare quantity_on_hand to reorder_point to find products needing restock.

tables.description: Customer master data including demographics, segmentation, and lifetime value. Contains approximately 10,000 customers segmented into Premium (10%), Athlete (20%), Regular (40%), and Bargain-Hunter (30%) tiers based on purchasing behavior. Includes PostGIS geography point for location-based analytics.

relationships.description: Each customer places zero or more orders
Each customer has one or more addresses
Each customer has one preference record
Each customer has segment history records
Customers may write product reviews
Customers receive email campaign events
Each customer has one nearest-store record in the view

knownIssues: location (PostGIS point) is populated for all customers
qualityNotes.freshness: updated as customers register and their segment/LTV changes

tables.usageNotes: Primary customer dimension table. Use customer_segment for tier-based analysis. lifetime_value is the cumulative total, not a modeled prediction. For segment change history, join to customer_segments_history. For nearest store, use the customer_nearest_store view instead of manual PostGIS calculations.

tables.description: Customer shipping and billing addresses. Supports multiple addresses per customer with a primary address flag. Used for order fulfillment and geographic analysis of the customer base.

relationships.description: Each address belongs to a customer

qualityNotes.freshness: updated when customers add or change addresses

tables.usageNotes: Filter on is_primary = true to get each customer's default address. For geographic analysis, prefer using customers.city/state/location unless you need the full shipping address.

tables.description: Customer shopping preferences and behavioral attributes. Tracks preferred product categories, shoe sizes, price sensitivity levels, and brand loyalty scores. One record per customer, used for personalization and marketing targeting.

relationships.description: 1:1 relationship with customers

tables.usageNotes: Join to customers for personalization analysis. preferred_category aligns with products.category values. Combine price_sensitivity with customer_segment for targeting matrix.

tables.description: Customer purchase orders across all sales channels. Each row represents a single order placed through online, retail partner, or direct channels. Contains approximately 131,000 orders from 2022-2025, all with completed status.

relationships.description: Each order belongs to one customer
Each order has 1-5 line items
Retail channel orders reference a partner
Orders may have associated returns
Each order has a shipment record
Orders aggregate into daily sales summary by channel

knownIssues: retail_partner_id is NULL for online and direct orders (~65% null)

tables.usageNotes: Primary fact table for sales analysis. Use order_date for business reporting, NOT created_at. Use daily_sales_summary for pre-aggregated daily metrics instead of aggregating this table when only channel-level daily totals are needed. For item-level detail, join to order_items.

tables.description: Individual line items within customer orders. Each row represents a single product in an order with quantity, pricing, and discount details. Links orders to products and contains the item-level financial breakdown.
tables.grain: One row per product per order

relationships.description: Each line item belongs to one order
Each line item references one product

tables.usageNotes: Use for product-level sales analysis. line_total = (quantity * unit_price) - discount_applied. Sum of line_total for an order equals orders.subtotal. For product performance metrics, prefer the product_performance view.

tables.description: Product return records linked to original orders. Tracks the return date, reason for return, and refund amount for each returned product. Used for return rate analysis, product quality issues, and financial impact assessment.
tables.grain: One row per returned product per order

relationships.description: Each return references the original order
Each return identifies the returned product

knownIssues: Return rate is ~6.5% of all orders

tables.usageNotes: Join to orders for customer context and to products for product-level return rate analysis. Calculate return rate as COUNT(returns) / COUNT(orders). Group by reason to identify top return drivers. refund_amount may be less than the original order item price for partial refunds.

tables.description: Retail distribution partner master data. Contains approximately 50 partners across department stores, specialty shoe retailers, and sporting goods stores. Includes geographic location (PostGIS point), commission rates, and partnership start dates.

relationships.description: Partners are referenced in retail-channel orders
Partners appear in the nearest-store view

tables.usageNotes: Dimension table for retail channel analysis. Join to orders via retail_partner_id (only populated on retail-channel orders). Use commission_rate to calculate partner cost on retail sales. PostGIS location enables spatial queries -- use customer_nearest_store view for pre-computed distances.

tables.description: Marketing campaign definitions and budgets. Each row represents a marketing campaign with its type, date range, budget allocation, target customer segment, and distribution channel (email, social, display). Used as the parent record for campaign performance tracking.

relationships.description: Each campaign has daily performance records
Email campaigns generate email events
Each campaign has one ROI summary row

knownIssues: target_segment is NULL for untargeted campaigns (~20%)
qualityNotes.freshness: updated when new campaigns are created

tables.usageNotes: Campaign dimension table. For quick ROI comparisons, use campaign_roi_summary view. For daily trend analysis, join to campaign_performance. channel here is the marketing channel (email/social/display), distinct from orders.order_channel (online/retail/direct).

tables.description: Daily performance metrics for marketing campaigns. Tracks impressions, clicks, conversions, spend, and attributed revenue per campaign per day. Used to calculate ROI, click-through rates, and cost-per-acquisition at the daily grain.
tables.grain: One row per campaign per day

relationships.description: Each performance record belongs to a campaign

tables.usageNotes: Use for daily campaign trending. Calculate CTR as clicks/impressions, conversion rate as conversions/clicks, ROAS as revenue_attributed/spend. For aggregate campaign-level ROI, prefer campaign_roi_summary view.

tables.description: Individual email marketing interaction events. Records each email touchpoint (sent, opened, clicked, unsubscribed, bounced) per customer per campaign. Used for email funnel analysis and engagement scoring.
tables.grain: One row per email event per customer per campaign

relationships.description: Each email event belongs to a campaign
Each email event is for a specific customer

knownIssues: Only email-channel campaigns generate email_events; social and display campaigns do not appear here

tables.usageNotes: Build email funnels by counting events per event_type for a campaign: sent > opened > clicked. Calculate open rate as COUNT(opened)/COUNT(sent), click rate as COUNT(clicked)/COUNT(opened). A customer can have multiple event types for the same campaign (e.g., sent + opened + clicked).

tables.description: Historical record of customer segment changes over time. Tracks when customers move between Premium, Athlete, Regular, and Bargain-Hunter tiers with the reason for each change. Enables cohort analysis and segment migration tracking.
tables.grain: One row per customer per segment period

relationships.description: Each segment history record belongs to a customer

knownIssues: segment_end_date is NULL for the current segment period

tables.usageNotes: Use to analyze segment migration patterns. The current segment is the row where segment_end_date IS NULL. To find customers who upgraded: look for rows where reason_for_change indicates a spend increase. Join to customers for current state, use this table for historical tracking.

tables.description: Pre-aggregated daily sales metrics by channel. Provides total orders, revenue, cost, profit, and average order value for each sales channel per day. Optimized for dashboards and trend reporting without needing to query the orders table directly.
tables.grain: One row per sales channel per day

relationships.description: Aggregated from orders table by date and channel

tables.usageNotes: Preferred table for daily sales trend dashboards and channel-level reporting. Use instead of aggregating the orders table when you only need daily channel totals. For item-level or product-level breakdowns, you must go back to orders + order_items.

tables.description: Monthly profit-and-loss summary for the business. Tracks revenue, cost of goods sold (COGS), marketing expense, operations expense, shipping expense, net profit, and profit margin percentage. Used for executive-level financial reporting and trend analysis.

qualityNotes.freshness: monthly batch, finalized after month close

tables.usageNotes: Executive-level P&L summary. month_date is always the 1st of the month. All expense categories are pre-computed. net_profit = revenue - cogs - marketing_expense - operations_expense - shipping_expense. For daily granularity, use daily_sales_summary instead.

tables.description: Daily website analytics metrics. Tracks sessions, unique visitors, page views, bounce rate, average session duration, and conversion rate. Used for digital marketing effectiveness and online funnel analysis.
tables.usageNotes: Use for web traffic trending and funnel analysis. conversion_rate is already calculated (no need to derive from orders). Combine with daily_sales_summary to correlate traffic with revenue. bounce_rate and conversion_rate are stored as decimals (0.45 = 45%).

tables.description: Daily customer acquisition metrics by marketing channel. Tracks the number of new customers acquired, total acquisition cost, and first-purchase revenue for each channel per day. Used for calculating customer acquisition cost (CAC) and channel efficiency.
tables.grain: One row per acquisition channel per day
tables.usageNotes: Calculate per-customer CAC as acquisition_cost / new_customers. Compare first_purchase_revenue to acquisition_cost for initial payback ratio. channel here refers to marketing/acquisition channels (email, social, display, organic, referral), not sales channels (online, retail, direct).

tables.description: Customer product reviews and ratings. Each row is a single review with a 1-5 star rating, free-text feedback, and verified purchase flag. Used for product quality monitoring, sentiment analysis, and customer satisfaction measurement.

relationships.description: Each review is for a specific product
Each review is written by a customer

knownIssues: review_text is NULL for ~15% of reviews (rating-only submissions)

tables.usageNotes: For product-level average ratings and review counts, prefer the product_performance view. Filter on verified_purchase = true for higher-quality review analysis. review_text supports free-text search for sentiment analysis.

tables.description: Shipment tracking and delivery performance data. Each row represents a shipment for an order with ship date, delivery date, carrier, shipping method, and on-time delivery flag. Used for logistics performance monitoring and carrier evaluation.
tables.grain: One row per shipment (one per order)

relationships.description: Each shipment is for a specific order

knownIssues: delivery_date is NULL for a small number of in-transit shipments (<0.5%)

tables.usageNotes: Calculate transit time as delivery_date - ship_date. Use on_time flag for SLA compliance metrics. Group by carrier or shipping_method to compare logistics performance. Join to orders for customer and channel context.

tables.description: Computed view that pairs each customer with their nearest retail partner store using PostGIS geographic distance calculations. Shows customer details, store details, and the calculated distance in miles. Used for omnichannel strategy and store assignment analysis.

relationships.description: Each row references a customer
Each row references the nearest retail partner

tables.usageNotes: Pre-computed view -- use this instead of writing PostGIS distance queries manually. Useful for analyzing how far customers are from retail locations and for store assignment. distance_miles is already calculated via ST_Distance.

tables.description: Aggregated view combining product catalog data with sales and review metrics. Shows total orders, units sold, revenue, average rating, and review count per product. Provides a single-query product scorecard for merchandising decisions.

relationships.description: Each row is a product from the catalog

knownIssues: avg_rating and num_reviews may be NULL for products with zero reviews

tables.usageNotes: Preferred table for product-level dashboards and ranking. Avoids the need to manually join order_items + products + product_reviews. Use for top/bottom product analysis, category comparisons, and revenue-per-product reporting.

tables.description: Pre-computed view that aggregates campaign performance into a single ROI summary per campaign. Joins campaigns with their cumulative performance metrics including total spend, impressions, clicks, conversions, revenue, and calculated ROI. Useful for quick campaign comparison without manual aggregation.

relationships.description: Each row is a campaign

tables.usageNotes: Preferred table for campaign-level ROI comparison and reporting. roi = (total_revenue - total_spend) / total_spend. For daily trends within a campaign, use campaign_performance instead. Includes budget for budget-utilization analysis (total_spend / budget).

columns.description: Unique identifier for each shoe product in the catalog
Marketing name of the shoe product (e.g., 'FireStride Pro', 'CloudRun Elite')
Primary product category. Values: 'running', 'basketball', 'casual', 'training', 'kids'

relationships.description: Values match the customer's preferred category

columns.description: Secondary product classification within the main category (e.g., 'trail', 'road', 'court')
columns.valuePattern: Lowercase single word describing use case or style

columns.description: FireKicks brand line or collection the product belongs to (e.g., 'Pro', 'Elite', 'Essential')
Manufacturing/wholesale cost per unit in USD. Used to calculate gross margin when compared to MSRP or actual selling price
columns.valuePattern: Positive decimal with 2 decimal places, USD
columns.usageNotes: Gross margin = msrp - base_cost. For actual margin on a sale, use order_items.unit_price - base_cost.

columns.description: Manufacturer's suggested retail price in USD. This is the list price before any discounts or promotions
columns.valuePattern: Positive decimal with 2 decimal places, USD, typically ends in .99
columns.usageNotes: List price, not actual selling price. For what customers actually paid, use order_items.unit_price.

columns.description: Date the product was first available for sale
Date the product was removed from active sale. NULL means the product is still active
columns.valuePattern: ISO 8601 date or NULL for active products
columns.usageNotes: Filter discontinued_date IS NULL to get active products. ~75% of products are still active.

knownIssues: NULL means still active, not missing data

columns.description: Primary color or colorway name for this product variant
Available size range for this product (e.g., '7-13', '1-6' for kids)
Foreign key to product_suppliers table. Identifies the manufacturing supplier for this product

relationships.description: Foreign key to supplier master data

columns.description: Unique identifier for each customer order
Foreign key to customers table. Identifies which customer placed this order

relationships.description: Foreign key to customer master data

columns.description: Date the order was placed by the customer. This is the business date used for sales reporting, not the system timestamp
columns.usageNotes: Use order_date for business reporting, NOT created_at. created_at is the system insert timestamp.

relationships.description: Aggregated by this date in daily sales summary

columns.description: Sales channel through which the order was placed. Values: 'online', 'retail', 'direct'

relationships.description: Values match daily sales summary channel dimension

columns.usageNotes: Distribution is approximately: online ~45%, retail ~35%, direct ~20%. This is the sales channel, distinct from marketing channels (email, social, display) in campaigns and customer_acquisition.

columns.description: Foreign key to retail_partners table. NULL for online and direct orders; populated only when order_channel is 'retail'

relationships.description: Foreign key to retail partner, only for retail orders

knownIssues: NULL is expected for non-retail orders, not a data quality issue

columns.description: Sum of all line item totals before tax, shipping, and order-level discounts. Calculated from order_items.line_total
columns.valuePattern: Positive decimal with 2 decimal places, USD
columns.usageNotes: subtotal = SUM(order_items.line_total) for this order. For the customer-facing total, use total_amount.

columns.description: Sales tax amount in USD calculated on the order subtotal
columns.valuePattern: Non-negative decimal with 2 decimal places, USD

columns.description: Shipping charge in USD billed to the customer for this order
columns.valuePattern: Non-negative decimal with 2 decimal places, USD. 0.00 for free shipping orders

columns.description: Order-level discount amount in USD. This is separate from item-level discounts in order_items.discount_applied
columns.valuePattern: Non-negative decimal with 2 decimal places, USD. 0.00 when no order-level discount
columns.usageNotes: This is the ORDER-level discount only. Item-level discounts are in order_items.discount_applied. Total discount for an order = discount_amount + SUM(order_items.discount_applied).

columns.description: Final order total in USD: subtotal + tax_amount + shipping_cost - discount_amount. This is what the customer pays
columns.valuePattern: Positive decimal with 2 decimal places, USD
columns.usageNotes: This is the customer-facing total. Use this for revenue reporting. Formula: subtotal + tax_amount + shipping_cost - discount_amount.

columns.description: Current status of the order in the fulfillment lifecycle
columns.usageNotes: Filter to shipped+delivered for revenue reports. Use pending+processing for pipeline analysis. Cancelled orders should be excluded from financial aggregations.

columns.description: System timestamp when the order record was inserted. Use order_date for business reporting
columns.usageNotes: System timestamp, NOT the business date. Always use order_date for reporting, trending, and aggregation.

columns.description: Unique identifier for each line item in an order
Foreign key to orders table. Links this line item to its parent order

relationships.description: Foreign key to parent order

columns.description: Foreign key to products table. Identifies which product was purchased in this line item

relationships.description: Foreign key to product catalog

columns.description: Number of units of this product purchased in this line item
Selling price per unit in USD at the time of purchase. May differ from products.msrp due to promotions or channel pricing
columns.valuePattern: Positive decimal with 2 decimal places, USD
columns.usageNotes: Actual selling price at time of purchase. May be lower than products.msrp due to discounts or promotions. For margin analysis, compare to products.base_cost.

columns.description: Item-level discount amount in USD applied to this line item. Separate from the order-level discount in orders.discount_amount
columns.valuePattern: Non-negative decimal with 2 decimal places, USD. 0.00 when no item discount
columns.usageNotes: Item-level discount only. Order-level discounts are in orders.discount_amount. line_total already accounts for this discount.

columns.description: Total amount for this line item in USD: (quantity * unit_price) - discount_applied. Rolls up to orders.subtotal
columns.valuePattern: Positive decimal with 2 decimal places, USD
columns.usageNotes: Pre-computed: (quantity * unit_price) - discount_applied. SUM(line_total) for an order equals orders.subtotal.

columns.description: Unique identifier for each customer in the system
Customer's first/given name
Customer's last/family name
Customer's email address. Used for account identification and marketing communications
Customer's phone number. Optional field, may be NULL
columns.valuePattern: US phone number format, may include dashes or parentheses

knownIssues: ~30% of customers have no phone number on file

columns.description: Customer's date of birth. Used for age demographics analysis and birthday promotions
Customer's gender for demographic segmentation and product targeting
Date the customer created their account. Used for customer tenure and cohort analysis
columns.usageNotes: Use for cohort analysis. registration_date is always before or on the customer's first order_date.

columns.description: Current customer tier classification. Values: 'Premium', 'Athlete', 'Regular', 'Bargain-Hunter'. Determined by purchase history, activity, and price sensitivity
columns.usageNotes: This is the CURRENT segment. For historical segment changes, use customer_segments_history. Distribution is approximately Premium ~10%, Athlete ~20%, Regular ~40%, Bargain-Hunter ~30%.

relationships.description: Values match segment history records
Campaigns may target specific segments

columns.description: Cumulative total revenue in USD generated by this customer across all orders. Updated as new orders are placed
columns.valuePattern: Non-negative decimal with 2 decimal places, USD
columns.usageNotes: Cumulative actual spend, not a modeled/predicted LTV. Should approximately equal SUM(orders.total_amount) for this customer.

columns.description: Customer's most-used shopping channel. Values: 'online', 'retail', 'direct'

relationships.description: Values match order channel dimension

columns.description: PostGIS geography point representing the customer's primary location (latitude/longitude). Used for spatial queries like nearest-store calculations
columns.usageNotes: Use the customer_nearest_store view instead of running PostGIS distance calculations directly. This is a geography type, not geometry -- distance calculations return meters by default.

columns.description: Customer's city of residence
Customer's state/province of residence (US state abbreviation)
Customer's postal/ZIP code
Unique identifier for the customer preference record
Foreign key to customers table. One preference record per customer

relationships.description: Foreign key to customer master data, 1:1

columns.description: Customer's preferred shoe category. Values: 'running', 'basketball', 'casual', 'training', 'kids'

relationships.description: Values match product category dimension

columns.description: Customer's shoe size (US sizing). Stored as string to accommodate half sizes and width modifiers
columns.valuePattern: Numeric string, may include .5 for half sizes (e.g., '9', '10.5')

columns.description: Customer's sensitivity to pricing. Values indicate willingness to pay (e.g., 'low', 'medium', 'high'). Higher sensitivity means more price-conscious
columns.usageNotes: 'high' means the customer is very price-sensitive (prefers discounts). 'low' means less price-sensitive (willing to pay full price).

columns.description: Numeric score indicating how loyal the customer is to FireKicks brand. Higher values indicate stronger brand affinity
columns.valuePattern: Decimal between 0 and 10, one decimal place

columns.description: Unique identifier for each address record
Foreign key to customers table. Multiple addresses allowed per customer

relationships.description: Foreign key to customer master data, many-to-one

columns.description: Street address line including house/building number
columns.valuePattern: Standard US street address (e.g., '123 Main St')

columns.description: City name for this address
US state abbreviation for this address
US postal ZIP code for this address
Country for this address. Defaults to 'US' for domestic addresses
columns.usageNotes: All addresses are domestic US. No filtering needed on country.

columns.description: Boolean flag indicating whether this is the customer's primary/default shipping address
columns.usageNotes: Filter is_primary = true to get one address per customer. Each customer has exactly one primary address.

columns.description: Unique identifier for each segment change record
Foreign key to customers table. Multiple records per customer as they change segments over time

relationships.description: Foreign key to customer master data

columns.description: The customer segment assigned during this period. Values: 'Premium', 'Athlete', 'Regular', 'Bargain-Hunter'

relationships.description: Values match the current segment in customer master

columns.description: Date when the customer entered this segment
Date when the customer exited this segment. NULL means the customer is currently in this segment
columns.valuePattern: ISO 8601 date or NULL for current segment

knownIssues: NULL means the customer is currently in this segment, not missing data

columns.usageNotes: To find the current segment row, filter WHERE segment_end_date IS NULL.

columns.description: Business reason why the customer's segment changed (e.g., 'spend increase', 'inactivity', 'initial assignment')
columns.usageNotes: Common values: 'initial assignment', 'spend increase', 'spend decrease', 'inactivity', 'reactivation', 'loyalty program'. Use for migration analysis.

columns.description: Unique identifier for each marketing campaign
Descriptive name of the marketing campaign (e.g., 'Summer Running Sale', 'Back to School 2024')
Type/category of marketing campaign (e.g., 'seasonal', 'product_launch', 'clearance', 'brand_awareness')
columns.valuePattern: Lowercase with underscores for multi-word types

columns.description: Date the campaign begins running
Date the campaign stops running
columns.valuePattern: ISO 8601 date, no time component. Always after start_date

columns.description: Total allocated budget for the campaign in USD
columns.valuePattern: Positive decimal with 2 decimal places, USD
columns.usageNotes: Allocated budget, not actual spend. Compare to campaign_roi_summary.total_spend for budget utilization.

columns.description: Customer segment this campaign is targeting. Values: 'Premium', 'Athlete', 'Regular', 'Bargain-Hunter', or NULL for untargeted

knownIssues: NULL means the campaign targets all segments, not missing data

relationships.description: Values match customer segment dimension

columns.description: Marketing distribution channel. Values: 'email', 'social', 'display'
columns.usageNotes: This is the MARKETING channel (email/social/display), distinct from the SALES channel (online/retail/direct) in orders.order_channel.

columns.description: Unique identifier for each daily campaign performance record
Foreign key to campaigns table. Links daily metrics to the parent campaign

relationships.description: Foreign key to campaign definitions

columns.description: Calendar date for this daily performance snapshot
Number of times the campaign ad/content was displayed to users on this date
Number of user clicks on the campaign ad/content on this date
columns.valuePattern: Positive integer, always less than impressions
columns.usageNotes: CTR = clicks / impressions. Typical CTR range is 2-6%.

columns.description: Number of campaign-attributed purchase conversions on this date. A conversion is a completed order tied to this campaign
columns.usageNotes: Conversion rate = conversions / clicks. CPA (cost per acquisition) = spend / conversions.

columns.description: Actual marketing spend in USD on this campaign for this date. May be less than the daily budget allocation
columns.valuePattern: Positive decimal with 2 decimal places, USD

columns.description: Total revenue in USD from orders attributed to this campaign on this date. Used to calculate ROAS (return on ad spend)
columns.valuePattern: Non-negative decimal with 2 decimal places, USD
columns.usageNotes: ROAS = revenue_attributed / spend. Daily ROI = (revenue_attributed - spend) / spend.

columns.description: Unique identifier for each daily acquisition record
Calendar date for this acquisition data point
Marketing channel that acquired these customers. Values: 'email', 'social', 'display', 'organic', 'referral'
columns.usageNotes: Acquisition channels include organic and referral in addition to paid channels (email, social, display). This is distinct from sales channels (online, retail, direct) in orders.

columns.description: Count of new customers acquired through this channel on this date
Total cost in USD spent to acquire new customers through this channel on this date. Divide by new_customers for per-customer CAC
columns.valuePattern: Non-negative decimal with 2 decimal places, USD
columns.usageNotes: CAC = acquisition_cost / new_customers. Be careful of division by zero when new_customers = 0.

columns.description: Total revenue in USD from first purchases by newly acquired customers on this date. Used to assess initial payback on acquisition spend
columns.valuePattern: Non-negative decimal with 2 decimal places, USD
columns.usageNotes: Initial payback ratio = first_purchase_revenue / acquisition_cost. Values > 1.0 mean the first purchase alone covers acquisition cost.

columns.description: Unique identifier for each email interaction event
Foreign key to campaigns table. Links this email event to the campaign that sent it

relationships.description: Foreign key to campaign definitions, only email campaigns

columns.usageNotes: Only email-channel campaigns appear here (~30 of 80 total campaigns). Filter campaigns.channel = 'email' when joining.

columns.description: Foreign key to customers table. Identifies which customer received/interacted with this email

relationships.description: Foreign key to customer master data

columns.description: Type of email interaction. Values: 'sent', 'opened', 'clicked', 'unsubscribed', 'bounced'. Forms a funnel: sent > opened > clicked
columns.usageNotes: Funnel order: sent > opened > clicked. unsubscribed and bounced are terminal events. A customer can have multiple event types per campaign (e.g., sent + opened + clicked).

columns.description: Exact date and time when the email event occurred. Use this for funnel timing analysis (e.g., time from send to open)
columns.usageNotes: Use DATE(event_timestamp) to aggregate by day. Calculate time-to-open as opened.event_timestamp - sent.event_timestamp for the same customer+campaign.

columns.description: Unique identifier for each product-warehouse inventory record
Foreign key to products table. Identifies which product this inventory record tracks

relationships.description: Foreign key to product catalog

columns.description: Name or code of the warehouse/distribution center where this inventory is held
columns.valuePattern: Descriptive warehouse name (e.g., 'East Coast DC', 'West Coast DC')

columns.description: Current number of units available in stock at this warehouse
columns.usageNotes: Compare to reorder_point to identify products needing restock. SUM across warehouses for total company-wide inventory.

columns.description: Minimum stock level that triggers a reorder. When quantity_on_hand falls below this, replenishment should be initiated
columns.usageNotes: Items needing restock: WHERE quantity_on_hand < reorder_point.

columns.description: Date of the most recent inventory replenishment for this product at this warehouse
Unique identifier for each supplier
Business name of the manufacturing supplier
Country where the supplier's manufacturing facilities are located
Average number of days from order placement to delivery from this supplier
Supplier quality score on a numeric scale. Higher values indicate better manufacturing quality and reliability
columns.valuePattern: Decimal between 3.0 and 5.0, one decimal place

columns.description: The main material this supplier specializes in (e.g., 'synthetic mesh', 'leather', 'rubber', 'foam')
Unique identifier for each product review
Foreign key to products table. Identifies which product is being reviewed

relationships.description: Foreign key to product catalog

columns.description: Foreign key to customers table. Identifies which customer wrote this review

relationships.description: Foreign key to customer master data

columns.description: Star rating from 1 to 5, where 1 is worst and 5 is best
Date the review was submitted by the customer
Free-text customer review content. May be NULL if the customer submitted only a star rating

knownIssues: ~15% of reviews are rating-only with no text

columns.description: Boolean flag indicating whether the reviewer has a confirmed purchase of this product in their order history
columns.usageNotes: Filter verified_purchase = true for more reliable review analysis. ~85% of reviews are verified purchases.

columns.description: Unique identifier for each retail distribution partner
Business name of the retail partner (e.g., store chain name)
Classification of the retail partner. Values: 'department_store', 'specialty_shoe', 'sporting_goods'
City where the retail partner store is located
US state where the retail partner store is located
PostGIS geography point for the store's physical location. Used for distance calculations in the customer_nearest_store view
columns.usageNotes: Use customer_nearest_store view for pre-computed customer-to-store distances instead of querying this directly with ST_Distance.

columns.description: Percentage commission rate paid to this retail partner on sales (e.g., 0.15 = 15%). Used for partner profitability analysis
columns.usageNotes: To calculate commission cost on a retail order: orders.total_amount * retail_partners.commission_rate. Higher commission = less profitable for FireKicks.

columns.description: Date when the partnership agreement with this retailer began
Unique identifier for each product return
Foreign key to orders table. Links the return to the original purchase order

relationships.description: Foreign key to the original order

columns.description: Foreign key to products table. Identifies which specific product was returned

relationships.description: Foreign key to product catalog

columns.description: Date the return was initiated by the customer
columns.valuePattern: ISO 8601 date, no time component. Always after the order's order_date

columns.description: Customer-stated reason for the return (e.g., 'wrong_size', 'defective', 'not_as_described', 'changed_mind')
columns.usageNotes: Most common reason is 'wrong_size' (~40%), followed by 'changed_mind' (~25%), 'defective' (~20%), 'not_as_described' (~15%). Use for product quality and sizing analysis.

columns.description: Amount in USD refunded to the customer for this return
columns.valuePattern: Positive decimal with 2 decimal places, USD
columns.usageNotes: May be less than the original purchase price for partial refunds or restocking fees. Sum for total refund exposure analysis.

columns.description: Unique identifier for each shipment
Foreign key to orders table. Links the shipment to the customer order

relationships.description: Foreign key to parent order, 1:1

columns.description: Date the order was shipped from the warehouse
columns.valuePattern: ISO 8601 date, no time component. Usually 1-2 days after order_date

columns.description: Date the shipment was delivered to the customer. NULL if not yet delivered. Calculate delivery_date - ship_date for transit time
columns.valuePattern: ISO 8601 date or NULL for in-transit shipments

knownIssues: NULL means the shipment is still in transit, not missing data

columns.usageNotes: Transit time = delivery_date - ship_date. Filter delivery_date IS NOT NULL for delivered shipments only.

columns.description: Shipping carrier company name (e.g., 'UPS', 'FedEx', 'USPS')
Shipping speed/tier selected for delivery (e.g., 'standard', 'express', 'overnight')
Boolean flag indicating whether the shipment was delivered on or before the promised delivery date
columns.usageNotes: On-time delivery rate = COUNT(on_time = true) / COUNT(*). Group by carrier or shipping_method for comparative SLA analysis. Overall on-time rate is ~92%.

columns.description: Calendar date for this daily sales summary record. Part of composite primary key with channel

relationships.description: Matches the business date on orders

columns.description: Sales channel for this summary row. Values: 'online', 'retail', 'direct'. One row per channel per day

relationships.description: Values match order channel dimension

columns.description: Count of completed orders for this channel on this date
Total revenue in USD from orders for this channel on this date (sum of orders.total_amount)
columns.valuePattern: Positive decimal with 2 decimal places, USD

columns.description: Total cost of goods sold in USD for this channel on this date
columns.valuePattern: Positive decimal with 2 decimal places, USD

columns.description: Gross profit in USD: total_revenue - total_cost. Does not include operating expenses
columns.valuePattern: Positive decimal with 2 decimal places, USD
columns.usageNotes: Gross profit only (revenue - COGS). For net profit including opex, use monthly_financials.

columns.description: Average order value in USD: total_revenue / total_orders. Key KPI for revenue optimization
columns.valuePattern: Positive decimal with 2 decimal places, USD
columns.usageNotes: Pre-computed: total_revenue / total_orders. Do not average this column across rows -- recompute as SUM(total_revenue) / SUM(total_orders) when aggregating across dates or channels.

columns.description: First day of the month this financial record covers (e.g., 2024-01-01 for January 2024)
columns.valuePattern: ISO 8601 date, always the 1st of the month
columns.usageNotes: Always the first day of the month. Use EXTRACT(YEAR FROM month_date) and EXTRACT(MONTH FROM month_date) for year/month grouping.

columns.description: Total revenue in USD for the month across all channels
columns.valuePattern: Positive decimal with 2 decimal places, USD

columns.description: Cost of goods sold in USD for the month. Represents the direct cost of products sold
columns.valuePattern: Positive decimal with 2 decimal places, USD

columns.description: Total marketing spend in USD for the month across all campaigns and channels
columns.valuePattern: Positive decimal with 2 decimal places, USD

columns.description: Monthly operations costs in USD including warehousing, staffing, and overhead
columns.valuePattern: Positive decimal with 2 decimal places, USD

columns.description: Total shipping and logistics costs in USD for the month
columns.valuePattern: Positive decimal with 2 decimal places, USD

columns.description: Net profit in USD: revenue - cogs - marketing_expense - operations_expense - shipping_expense
columns.valuePattern: Decimal with 2 decimal places, USD. Can theoretically be negative but is positive in this dataset
columns.usageNotes: net_profit = revenue - cogs - marketing_expense - operations_expense - shipping_expense. All months are profitable in this dataset.

columns.description: Net profit margin as a decimal (e.g., 0.15 = 15%). Calculated as net_profit / revenue
columns.usageNotes: Pre-computed: net_profit / revenue. Do not average this column across months -- recompute as SUM(net_profit) / SUM(revenue) for multi-month margins.

columns.description: Unique identifier for each daily website traffic record
Calendar date for this website traffic snapshot
columns.valuePattern: ISO 8601 date, no time component. One row per day

columns.description: Total number of website sessions (visits) on this date. A session is a group of interactions within a time frame
Number of distinct visitors to the website on this date. Lower than sessions since one visitor can have multiple sessions
Total number of pages viewed across all sessions on this date
columns.usageNotes: Pages per session = page_views / sessions. Higher pages/session indicates better engagement.

columns.description: Percentage of single-page sessions as a decimal (e.g., 0.45 = 45%). Lower is better, indicating visitors explore beyond the landing page
columns.usageNotes: Lower is better. Do not average across days -- recompute as weighted average using sessions as weight.

columns.description: Average session duration in seconds for this date. Higher values indicate more engaged visitors
columns.usageNotes: Stored in seconds. Divide by 60 for minutes. Do not average across days -- use session-weighted average.

columns.description: Percentage of sessions that resulted in a purchase as a decimal (e.g., 0.03 = 3%). Key ecommerce KPI
columns.usageNotes: Pre-computed conversion rate. Typical range 1-6%. Do not average across days -- recompute as total conversions / total sessions.

columns.description: Campaign identifier from the campaigns table

relationships.description: References campaign definitions

columns.description: Name of the marketing campaign
Type/category of the marketing campaign
Campaign start date
Campaign end date
Allocated campaign budget in USD
columns.valuePattern: Positive decimal with 2 decimal places, USD
columns.usageNotes: Budget utilization = total_spend / budget. Values near or above 1.0 indicate full budget spend.

columns.description: Cumulative actual spend in USD across all days of the campaign
columns.valuePattern: Positive decimal with 2 decimal places, USD

columns.description: Cumulative ad impressions across the entire campaign duration
Cumulative ad clicks across the entire campaign duration
columns.usageNotes: Campaign CTR = total_clicks / total_impressions.

columns.description: Cumulative purchase conversions attributed to this campaign
columns.usageNotes: CPA = total_spend / total_conversions. Conversion rate = total_conversions / total_clicks.

columns.description: Cumulative revenue in USD attributed to this campaign
columns.valuePattern: Positive decimal with 2 decimal places, USD

columns.description: Return on investment calculated as (total_revenue - total_spend) / total_spend. A value of 2.0 means $2 return per $1 spent
columns.usageNotes: roi = (total_revenue - total_spend) / total_spend. Values > 1.0 mean the campaign was profitable. ROAS (return on ad spend) = total_revenue / total_spend = roi + 1.

columns.description: Customer identifier from the customers table

relationships.description: References customer master data

columns.description: Customer's first name
Customer's last name
Customer's current segment tier (Premium, Athlete, Regular, Bargain-Hunter)
City where the customer is located
State where the customer is located
Identifier of the nearest retail partner store to this customer

relationships.description: References the nearest retail partner

columns.description: Name of the nearest retail partner store
City where the nearest retail partner store is located
State where the nearest retail partner store is located
Geographic distance in miles between the customer and their nearest retail partner store, calculated using PostGIS ST_Distance
columns.usageNotes: Pre-computed from PostGIS ST_Distance. Use for store catchment analysis. Average distance varies significantly by state/region.

columns.description: Product identifier from the products table

relationships.description: References product catalog

columns.description: Name of the product
Product category (running, basketball, casual, training, kids)
FireKicks brand line/collection this product belongs to
Manufacturer's suggested retail price in USD
columns.valuePattern: Positive decimal with 2 decimal places, USD

columns.description: Total number of orders containing this product
Total quantity of units sold across all orders
columns.usageNotes: total_units_sold >= num_orders because some orders contain multiple units of the same product.

columns.description: Cumulative revenue in USD generated by this product across all orders
columns.valuePattern: Positive decimal with 2 decimal places, USD

columns.description: Average customer review rating (1-5 scale) for this product
columns.valuePattern: Decimal between 1.0 and 5.0, one decimal place, or NULL if no reviews

knownIssues: NULL for products with zero reviews (~2.5%)

columns.description: Total number of customer reviews submitted for this product
columns.usageNotes: Products with num_reviews = 0 will have avg_rating = NULL. Consider filtering to products with at least 10 reviews for meaningful rating comparisons.
